title: Exponential Functions
content:
Exponential growth and decay appear in real - world problems about population, money, and radioactive decay. The key is recognizing the pattern: the quantity multiplies by a constant factor in each time period!

What is Exponential Growth?

Exponential Growth Formula: y = a(1 + r)ᵗ

  • a: Initial amount
  • r: Growth rate (as decimal)
  • t: Time periods

Growth vs. Decay

Growth (Increase)

y = a(1 + r)ᵗ

Use when quantity INCREASES by r% each period

Example: Population grows 5% per year

y = a(1.05)ᵗ

y = a(1 − r)ᵗ

Decay (Decrease)

Use when quantity DECREASES by r% each period: Example:

Value depreciates 20% per year: y = a(0.80)ᵗ

Step-by-Step Example

Example

A population of 500 grows 8% per year. What's the population after 3 years?

Step 1: Identify the values:

Step 2: Use the growth formula
a = 500 (initial population) r = 0.08 (8% as decimal) t = 3 (years) y = a(1 + r)ᵗ y = 500(1 + 0.08)³ y = 500(1.08)³

Step 3: Calculate: Compound interest is a special case of exponential growth where money grows based on interest rate!
1.08³ ≈ 1.2597 500 × 1.2597 ≈ 629.85 Population ≈ 630

Compound Interest

Compound Interest Formula: A = P(1 + r/n)ⁿᵗ:P= Principal (initial amount):r= Annual interest rate (as decimal):n= Times compounded per year:t= Number of years

Example Problem

Example 1

Problem:A car worth $20,000 depreciates 15% per year. What's its value after 2 years?

A. $14,450
B. $15,000
C. $16,500
D. $17,000

Solution:Use decay formula: y = a(1 − r)ᵗ

y = 20000(1 − 0.15)² y = 20000(0.85)² y = 20000(0.7225) y = $14,450

Answer: A

Key Takeaway

Growth: multiply by (1 + r). Decay: multiply by (1 − r). The exponent t is always the number of time periods. Convert percentages to decimals before calculating!
